titlestmt.title: Illustrations to Milton's "Paradise Lost"The Thomas Set: electronic edition
titlestmt.principal: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
titlestmt.sponsor: The Library of Congress and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with a software grant from Inso Corporation and hardware and software grants from Sun Microsystems

filedesc.extent: 1 XML file approx. 18KB; 24 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 150KB to 1300KB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; Carolina Digital Library and ArchivesJanuary 2008
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of an electronic edition of Blake's illustrations to John Milton's Paradise Lost. This group of twelve water colors was acquired, and probably commissioned, by the Rev. Joseph Thomas in 1807. These designs, not in the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery, are presented in our Preview mode, one that provides all the features of the Archive except Image Search and Inote (our image annotation program).
Here, as usual in his work as an illustrator of other poets' works, Blake paid close attention to the text, but this disciplined approach did not preclude his own interpretations. For example, Blake's choice of subjects places greater emphasis on Christ's role in Milton's epic than most series of eighteenth- and nineteenth-century illustrations of Paradise Lost.
With this publication, the Archive contains six of Blake's nine series of water colors illustrating Milton's poetry. It is our intention to publish in the near future the remaining three series: the Butts and Linnell sets of illustrations to Paradise Lost and the Butts set of designs for "On the Morning of Christ's Nativity."
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

Permission to reproduce the graphic images in this archive has been granted by the owners of the originals for this publication only.
This image copyright © 2008 Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.

objtitle.title: *Illustrations to Milton's "Paradise Lost,"* The Thomas Set

objdescid.compdate: 1807The date of composition is established by the inscribed date on Objects 4, 8, 9, 11, and 12.

objinfo.leafsize: approximately 25.5 x 21.0 cm.The leaves appear to have been trimmed slightly, as indicated by the way the inscriptions are trimmed into on several designs.
objinfo.watermark: BUTTANSHAWThe watermark appears only on Objects 3 and 10.
objinfo.framelines: There are traces of a border line along the top edge of Object 6, along the bottom and right edges of Object 8, and along the right edges of Objects 9 and 11.

provenance.name: Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery
provenance.date: Objects 1-4, 7-12 acquired in 1911; Objects 5 and 6 acquired in 1914
provenance.dealer: Rosenbach Company (A. S. W. Rosenbach) for Objects 1-4, 7-12; no record for Objects 5 and 6
provenance.price: $17,000 for Objects 1-4, 7-12; no record for Objects 5 and 6
provenance.note: Acquired directly from Blake, and probably commissioned, by Joseph Thomas; by inheritance to his grandson Drummond Percy Chase; sold anonymously at Sotheby's, 2 August 1872, lot 156 (£100 to the dealers Ellis and Green); Alfred Aspland by 1876; sold from his collection in individual lots, Sotheby's, 27 January 1885, lots 77-88; Objects 1-4, 7-12 purchased by the dealer Pincott, lot 77 (Object 1) for £6, lot 78 (Object 2) for £5.5s., lot 79 (Object 3) for £4, lot 81 (Object 4) for £5, lot 82 (Object 7) for £5, lot 84 (Object 8) for £7, lot 85 (Object 9) for £6, lot 86 (Object 10) for £7, lot 87 (Object 11) for £6, and lot 88 (Object 12) for £7; lots 80 and 83 (Objects 5 and 6) bought by the dealer Gray for £10 each; Objects 1-4, 7-12 acquired by Sydney Style; this group sold from his collection, Sotheby's, 15 December 1906, lot 481 (£2000 to the dealer Frank T. Sabin); this group sold by the Rosenbach Company in 1911 to Henry E. Huntington ($17,000); Objects 5 and 6 acquired by J. Annan Bryce by 1904; these two objects apparently sold privately to Henry E. Huntington in 1914.

repository.institution: Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery

desc.objtitle: Satan Calling Up His Legions, Object 1 (Butlin 529.1)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the center of the design, Satan stands on a large stone in hell, arms raised at 135 degrees, and surrounded by fifteen other figures. His mouth is open and he is probably speaking to the other fallen angels. A spear and round sheild lean against a stone to the right of Satan. Eight figures appear to the right of Satan; two of the most prominent figures in this group hover or leap with their arms raised above their heads and look to the left toward Satan. The figure at the bottom of this group kneels with his back to the viewer and his left hand placed palm down on the ground. Four figures bound by chains appear below Satan. The rightmost figure lies supine with his head toward the viewer and his eyes closed. To the left sits a figure with his legs drawn up to his chest and his arms wrapped around his lower legs. To the left, a figure kneels and is seen from behind with his left arm behind his back. The leftmost figure on the bottom row crouches in a cave. To the left of Satan, a nude figure hovers or leaps upward. He is seen from behind and has both arms raised above his head. Along the left edge of the design is a figure with its arms raised vertically. The head of a second figure appears above him. To the left of Satan, a figure sits on a stone with his body twisted away from the viewer and his right leg extending to the right. The figures are surrounded by fire, indicating hell. Fire also cascades like a river or waterfall between the rocks to the left of Satan. Coloring at the bottom of the design may represent the shore of the lake of fire described in Milton's poem. Thick columns of smoke or dark clouds rise left and right of Satan.

component.illusobjdesc: In the center of the design, a nude and muscular Satan (a fallen angel becoming a devil) stands on a large stone. He faces forward with his genitals visible; there is an indication of scales around his loins. His arms are raised at 135 degrees with palms facing outward; the fingers on both hands are spread. His hair is curly and slightly flame-like over the center of his forehead. His mouth is open and he is probably speaking to the other figures surrounding him. His knitted brow suggests a combination of melancholy and despair, in spite of his heroic stance.
A spear and a round shield rest against a stone to the right of Satan.

A muscular nude male (one of the fallen angels) hovers as the largest figure to the right of Satan. His body faces forward with his genitals visible. His head is turned in profile to the left and he looks toward Satan. The figure's legs are bent to the right; his hair is long and curly. Both of his arms are bent upward; his right arm wraps around his head, while his left is raised above his head with the palm held vertically.

A muscular nude male (one of the fallen angels) hovers to the right of Satan and just within the right margin of the design. His body faces forward with his left leg drawn up (the knee prominent) and his right leg bent slightly. His right arm is raised vertically with the palm facing up. He holds a spear in his left hand. The figure's head is turned to the left. His hair is short and slightly curly, and his mouth may be slightly open. He appears to look toward Satan.

The head of a figure (one of the fallen angels, and hence male) appears above the largest hovering nude male to the right of Satan. He faces left and up and likely looks (eyes raised) toward Satan. His hair is medium length and his mouth may be slightly open. His right arm is raised vertically and he holds a spear in his right hand. The rest of his body is not pictured.

The head and right shoulder of a figure (one of the fallen angels, and hence male) is seen left of the largest hovering male's abdomen. He faces left and looks, with eyes raised, toward Satan. His hair is curly.
The head and shoulders of a male figure (one of the fallen angels) appear left of the largest hovering male's knees. He faces forward, mouth possibly open, and has curly hair.

The head and right shoulder of a figure (one of the fallen angels, and hence male) appear below the knees of the largest hovering male to the right of Satan. He faces left and up with his head bent back; the figure looks, eyes raised, toward Satan. There are slight indications of flame-like hair.

The head, right shoulder, and upper torso of a male figure (one of the fallen angels) appears below the largest hovering male to the right of Satan. His body appears to be twisted to the right, while his head faces left and up. He has flame-like hair and his mouth is open. His head is bent back as he looks, eyes raised, toward Satan.

In the lower right corner of the design, a muscular nude male (one of the fallen angels) is seen from behind. He kneels in a crouching position with his left leg bent underneath him; his right leg is not pictured. Both arms are bent and are braced with his left hand on the ground below, palm down. His right hand rests on a stone to the right. His hair is curly. His head is bent back and he looks, left eye raised, up and to the left toward Satan.

A nude male (one of the fallen angels) lies supine on the ground below Satan. He is upside down with his head down toward the viewer. He is bearded with curly hair. His eyes may be closed (note the absence of pupils); he may be dead. His arms are not pictured, but his prominent shoulders rest on the ground. His legs are bent and drawn slightly up; his left leg may lean against the figure to the left. He may be bound by the chain to the right. Although his arms are not pictured, the position of his shoulders suggests that his arms are extended outward, thereby hinting at a cruciform position.
A chain with four distinct links is attached to a rock above and to the right of the supine figure.

A nude male (one of the fallen angels) sits on the ground directly below Satan. His prominent knees are drawn up to his chest and only his right foot is visible. His arms are bent and wrap around his legs. His right hand lies over his left; both are at his ankles and the left touches the ground or rock below. Each wrist is bound by a large shackle connected to a chain; at least the chain on his left wrist appears to be attached to the ground or the rock below. His hair is curly. His head is raise and he casts his eyes up toward Satan.

A muscular nude male (one of the fallen angels) kneels below and slightly to the left of Satan. He is seen from behind and leans to the right; his legs are spread with the left leg back and both feet on tiptoe. His left arm is behind his back while his right appears to be positioned at his side. His hands rest on the ground. Each wrist is bound by a large shackle connected to a chain, in turn apparently attached to the ground or a rock below. The figure's head is bent back and faces right as he looks, right eye raised, toward Satan.

In the lower left corner of the design, a muscular nude male (one of the fallen angels) crouches, squats, or lunges forward at the mouth of a cave. His left leg is bent beneath him, knee and foot prominent; his right leg is not pictured. Both arms are bent and braced to support the figure. His left hand is on the ground, palm down, with a shackle on his wrist. A single link of a chain is attached to the shackle. The figure's body faces forward with his head turned right and up in profile. His head is bent back and he looks up toward Satan. His hair is curly and his mouth may be slightly open.
A figure crouches or lunges at the mouth of a small cave in the lower left corner of the design. The flames on either side of the figure suggest that this cave is also a type of furnace.

A muscular nude male (one of the fallen angels) hovers or leaps upward to the left of Satan. He is seen from behind. His right leg is bent with the sole of his foot turned toward the viewer. His left arm is bent upward above his head with his palm held vertically. His right arm is raised vertically with his palm up and the fingers slightly spread. The figure's head is bent back and faces to the right; he may look toward Satan. His hair is slightly curly.

On the left edge of the design, the head, arms, and a bit of the upper body of a figure (one of the fallen angels, and hence male) appear above a large stone. The figure's arms are raised vertically with the palms turned up and out to face the viewer. The figure's mouth may be open, his fingers may be spread, and his eyes may be raised.
The head of a figure (one of the fallen angels, and hence male) appears on the left edge of the design, above the figure with its arms raised vertically.

A muscular nude male (one of the fallen angels) sits and partly reclines on a stone behind and to the left of Satan. His body faces away from the viewer and is seen from behind. His right leg is bent and extends to the right; his left leg is not pictured. His right foot is prominent. His left arm is bent upward and rests on a stone to the left. His head may rest on his left hand in a position that hints at melancholy. The figure's body twists away from the viewer and leans slightly to the left; his head is turned to the left and faces down. His hair is somewhat curly.
Several figures in the scene stand, sit, or kneel on large stones or boulders. The general impression is of a rocky and fiery landscape of hell.

The scene is surrounded by tongues of flame, particularly on the left and right of the design, as well as behind the figures in the bottom row. Fire also cascades like a river or waterfall between the rocks to the left of Satan. Coloring at the bottom of the design may suggest the shore of the lake of fire from Milton's poem.
Dark clouds or smoke rise to the left and right of Satan.

lg.l: 18The date (presumably 1807) is cut off by the trimmed right edge of the leaf.

WBThis signature may be only the initials visible on the leaf, but it might be the beginning of a full "WBlake" signature cut off by the trimmed right edge. Both forms appear on other designs in the series.

desc.objtitle: Satan, Sin, and Death: Satan Comes to the Gates of Hell, Object 2 (Butlin 529.2)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Satan and Death stand fighting with Sin between them. Satan, on the left, strides to the right with his arms bent upward. He holds a spear in his raised right hand and an oval shield in his left. Death's body is transparent. He lunges to the left with his arms raised above his head; with both hands he holds a fiery spear or dart which is pointed at Satan. Sin kneels between the two figures with her arms raised and braced against them as if to separate them. Below her loins are two coiled serpent's tails and the heads of three hell hounds. A key attached to a chain dangles to the right of Death's right calf. The scene takes place in a chamber or hall with an open archway on the left and a large gate, with a lowered portcullis, on the right. These are the gates of hell. A chain hangs from the upper edge of the design. Fire fills the archway on the left and appears along the lower edge of the design below the figures and the plinth-like (stone?) floor on which they stand.

component.illusobjdesc: Satan strides and looks to the right, towards the figure of Death, with his right leg prominent and left foot on tiptoe. He is nude with curly hair. Satan's mouth is open and his brow is furrowed; his expression suggests anger. Both arms are bent upward and are raised at approximately 135 degrees. Satan holds a spear in his right hand and an oval shield with belt-like straps in his left hand; he is fighting with (or about to fight with) Death. His hair is curly and slightly flame-like.

Death lunges or strides to the left (towards Satan) with his legs spread. His lower body faces forward, but his upper body and head are twisted to the left. His body is transparent. Death is bearded and wears a crown; his left foot is on tiptoe. His mouth is open and his brow is furrowed; his expression suggests anger. His hair is long and flame-like. Both arms are raised above his head; his left arm is raised at 135 degrees while his right is bent over his head. He grasps a fiery spear or dart with both hands; he is fighting with (or about to fight with) Satan.

A nude female representing Sin kneels between the figures of Satan and Death. She faces forward with her head tilted to the left. Her mouth is open and she may be speaking or howling. She looks up and to the left, eyes raised, toward Satan. Her long, flame-like hair falls behind her shoulders and down her back. Both arms are bent upward at 90 degree angles. Her hands and forearms are braced against the chests of Satan and Death; she is likely pushing them apart in an effort to stop the fight. Below Sin's loins, the scale-covered tails of two coiled serpents form a spiral extending to the left and right. The heads of three hell hounds also appear at Sin's genitals. Their mouths are open with tongues extended and teeth visible; they may be barking. The head on the right is tilted upward.
A large key attached to a chain appears to the right of Death's right leg. This is likely Sin's key to the gates of hell as described in Milton's poem (2:725).

The scene takes place in a hall or chamber (made of stone?) with an open archway on the left and a large gate with lowered iron portcullis on the right. These are the gates of hell. The vertical bars of the portcullis terminate in points similar to Death's spear of dart. A large chain hangs from the upper edge of the design. Fire fills the archway on the left and appears along the lower edge of the design below the figures and the plinth-like (stone?) floor on which they stand.

desc.objtitle: Christ Offers to Redeem Man, Object 3 (Butlin 529.3)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Christ hovers in the center of the design facing away from the viewer. He is gowned and has long hair. His left leg extends backward. Christ's arms are raised at 135 degrees with his palms facing out (away from the viewer) and his fingers slightly spread. His posture suggests the crucifixion. God the Father sits on a simple throne (raised on a plinth or three stairs) in the center of the design. His head is down and may rest on Christ's left shoulder, and he touches or lightly embraces Christ with his hands. His posture suggests grief. Beams of light radiate outward from God. A group of four gowned angels fly or hover upside down to the left and right of Christ. Each angel holds a crown which they may be giving or offerering to Christ. A band of clouds separates the upper, heavenly part of the scene from the bottom. Below, Satan hovers or flies to the left on bat-like wings with body horizontal. His right arm is raised and he holds a spear in his right hand. His shield is strapped to his left arm. His visage suggests a mixture of sorrow and anger.

component.illusobjdesc: Christ hovers in the center of the design facing away from the viewer. He is gowned and has long hair. His left leg extends backward with the left foot prominent. Christ's arms are raised at 135 degrees with his palms facing out (away from the viewer) and his fingers slightly spread. His posture suggests the crucifixion.

God the Father sits facing forward on a simple throne in the center of the design. He is gowned and appears to have long hair. He bows or bends forward, head down, and may rest his head on Christ's left shoulder. Both arms are bent and rest on his lap. He touches or lightly embraces Christ with his large, prominent hands. God's right foot is visible below the hem of his gown. His posture suggests grief. Beams of light radiate outward from the figure of God.
God sits on a throne with a plinth or three stairs below.

A group of four gowned angels fly downward or hover upside down to the left and right of Christ. The angels on the left face down and right, while those on the right face down and left. Each angel has a single arm bent and holds a crown; they may be giving or offering the crowns to Christ. The angel farthest from the viewer on the left has curly hair; the other three have long hair. One foot of each front-most angel is prominent.
A band of clouds separates the top, heavenly portion of the scene from the bottom portion where Satan appears.

Satan hovers or flies to the left on bat-like wings at the bottom of the design. He is nude with scales covering his genitals. His body is partly horizontal and faces left with his head is turned back toward the right. His hair is curly. His left arm is at his side and he holds a shield strapped to his left arm. His right arm is raised at 135 degrees (relative to his body) and he holds a spear in his right hand. His visage suggests a mixture of anger and sorrow.
The sky (or the void or chaos outside heaven?) below the cloud band is dark, possibly cloudy, lower left.

lg.l: 180The final numeral of the date is cut off by the trimmed right edge of the leaf, except for what is probably the lower reaches of the number "7."

desc.objtitle: Satan Spying on Adam and Eve and Raphael's Descent into Paradise, Object 4 (Butlin 529.4)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Satan stands in the left part of the design among barren trees. He is nude and has large bat-like wings. A serpent rises above Satan's head and wraps around his hips and right leg. The serpent's mouth is open with its tongue extended and teeth visible. Adam and Eve stand together in the right section of the design. They walk away from the viewer and look at each other. They may hold hands. The trunks of two leafy trees are visible left and right of Adam and Eve. A vine with several bunches of grapes and grape leaves coils around each tree. Additional leafy vegetation fills the space between the trees. The lush vegetation represents Eden. In the center of the design, the winged angel Raphael descends from Heaven on a V-shaped cloud, separating Satan from Adam and Eve. Hhis arms are bent with his hands over his chest. Rapahel's head is bent back and he looks up toward God. God flies or hovers on outstretched wings at the top of the design with only his head, flowing beard, arms, and wings visible. He faces out toward the viewer with his eyes cast downward.

component.illusobjdesc: Satan stands on tiptoe in the left part of the design among barren trees. He is muscular, nude, and has large bat-like wings. He stands with his right leg crossed in front of his left. Both arms are bent with his hands raised and his palms facing out toward the viewer. The fingers on his right hand are slightly spread. He looks to the right toward the figures of Adam and Eve. A serpent rises above Satan's head and wraps around his hips and right leg as though the creature had him partly bound. His knitted brow suggests a combination of envy, fear, and despair.

A snake or serpent covered in scales rises above Satan's head and coils itself around his hips and right leg. Its tail trails off to the left below Satan's feet. The serpent's mouth is open with its tongue extended and teeth visible. The serpent's head is topped with a spiky crest.

Satan stands between two barren trees in the left section of the design. The trunks of two more trees stand on either side of the V-shaped cloud. The leftmost tree has several twisted, partly intertwined, and leafless branches.

Adam is seen from behind on the right side of the design. He is nude and walks away from the viewer, left foot on tiptoe, with his arms at his sides and the palm of his left hand turned down. He may hold Eve's left hand with his right (the position of her left hand is not clear). His head is turned to the right as he looks at Eve. His hair is curly.

Eve is seen from behind on the right side of the design. She is nude with long, curly hair and walks away from the viewer, right foot on tiptoe, with her arms at her sides. She may hold Adam's right hand with her left, although the position of her left hand is not clear. Her right palm is vertical. Her head is turned to the left and she looks at Adam.

The trunks of two slender and leafy trees are visible left and right of Adam and Eve. A vine with several bunches of grapes and grape leaves coils around each tree. Additional leafy vegetation fills the space between the trees and, in the distance, the area above the heads of Adam and Eve. The lush vegetation represents Eden.
Raphael descends from Heaven on a large, V-shaped column of clouds that extends diagonally to the top left and right corners of the design, separating Satan from Adam and Eve.

In the center of the design, the winged angel Raphael descends from Heaven as though riding on a V-shaped cloud. The position of his feet suggest that he is also walking toward the viewer or about to step on to the ground below. He is nude and stands facing forward. Two of his multiple wings extend between his upper thighs. Both arms are bent with his hands on his chest and his fingers slightly spread. His head is bent back in left profile and he looks up toward God. is hair is long and flame-like.

At the top of the design, God flies, floats, or hovers on outstretched wings with only his head, wings, flowing beard, and arms visible. His hair is long. His arms are raised horizontally with the palms turned down. His eyes appear to be cast down and he may be looking at Raphael.
Grass covers the ground at the bottom of the design, except for an apparently barren patch below the feet of Adam and Eve.

The background behind Satan, possibly the sky, and below the lower reaches of the cloud is very dark. A few, faint horizontal lines in the sky below God hint at either steps or bands of clouds. An uncolored area above God's head hints at a slight radiance.

desc.objtitle: Satan Watching the Endearments of Adam and Eve, Object 5 (Butlin 529.5)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Adam and Eve kiss while embracing in Eden. Both figures are nude, and Adam wears a crown or wreath of flowers on his head. The couple sits on a mound or bed of flowers and leaves. Large plants bearing leaves (laurel, according to Milton's poem) and slender branches bearing twelve rose blossoms rise left and right of the couple and arch over them. The plant on the left also contains small clusters of buds or fruit in the center of the leaves. Other plants cover the ground below the couple, including several lily-like flowers. Satan flies or hovers on outstretched wings above Adam and Eve with his body horizontal. A serpent covered in scales encircles Satan's upper body, right leg, and left arm. Satan and the serpent (or his own serpent-self) look at each other, much as Adam and Eve gaze at each other below. On the left of the design, the sun is visible on the horizon above the sea, suggesting sunrise or sunset. Beams of light emanate from the sun. The moon appears in the upper right of the design. Two stars also appear in the night sky; one is directly above the moon while the other is pictured above Satan within (or behind?) his left wing.

component.illusobjdesc: Adam and Eve kiss while seated on a bed of flowers. Adam is muscular and nude; he faces forward with his head turned to the left in profile as he looks intently at Eve. Adam wears a crown or wreath of flowers on his head. He sits with his right leg drawn up and his left leg bent and crossed behind his right. His left arm is bent and rests on the bed of flowers; his left hand rests against his hip. With his right arm, Adam holds or embraces Eve. His right hand holds the back of Eve's head with his fingers spread in her hair. Adam's hair is curly.

Adam and Eve rest on a mound or bed of buds and flowersprobably rosesand leaves. Large plants bearing leaves (laurel, according to Milton's text) twelve rose blossoms on slender branches rise left and right of the couple and arch above them. The plant on the left contains small clusters of berriesperhaps twelve in allin the center of the leaves. Other plants cover the ground below the couple, including several lily-like flowers. The setting is Eden.

Satan flies or hovers on outstretched wings above Adam and Eve. He is nude with dark-colored skin and curly hair. Satan's body is horizontal with his legs extended to the right. His right arm is bent and is at his side; he points towards Adam and Eve with his right hand. His head is turned to the right and he looks towards the serpent whose head he holds with his left hand. Satan is encircled by the serpent (or his serpent-self) as though bound.

A serpent covered in scales encircles Satan's upper body, right leg, and left arm. The serpent's head faces left in profile and looks at Satan. Their mutual gaze imitates (or parodies) the mutual gaze of Adam and Eve below. The serpent's head is topped with a spiky crest.
On the left of the design, the sun is visible on the horizon above the sea, suggesting sunrise or sunset. Beams of light emanate from the sun.

The moon appears in the upper right of the design. A crescent is illuminated, but we also see the dark part of the moon. Two stars also appear in the night sky; one is directly above the moon while the other is pictured above Satan and within (or behind) his left wing. The night sky is dark.

lg.l: WBlakThe final letter of Blake's signature, and the lower reaches of the penultimate letter, are cut off by the trimmed right and lower edges of the leaf.

desc.objtitle: Raphael Warns Adam and Eve, Object 6 (Butlin 529.6)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The winged angel Raphael sits in Eden at a vegetative table with Adam and Eve. Raphael's arms are raised and 135 degrees; he points upward with his left hand and points towards the Tree of Knowledge with his right. His wings form a Gothic arch over his head. Adam and Eve sit on the left side of the table. They are both nude. Adam looks up toward the Tree of Knowledge, while Eve casts her gaze downward and perhaps leans toward Adam. A large bowl filled with leaves and fruit rests on the table beside a goblet or chalice and a pitcher with a looped handle. The ground below the figures is covered with copious vegetation, including leaves and flowers. Several oak-like leaves are visible between the vegetative "legs" of the table. Large leafy laurel plants grow left and right of the scene; rose and lily blossoms spring from these slender branches that arch over the scene. Small berries also grow among the leaves on both the left and right. In the lower left corner of the design, a lily plant bends to the right with most of its flowers on the ground. A rose plant mirrors this in the lower right corner of the design, bending left. In the upper center of the design in the middle distance is the Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil. There are thorns on the trunk and along some of the branches. Multiple branches arch to the left and right of the central trunk and bear large fruits and several leaves. A serpent coils around the trunk of the Tree of Knowledge, its head facing right. The serpent is covered in scales. It has a beak-like nose and a crest on the top of its head. Several other animals appear in the middle distance, including a horse, an elephant, a peacock with its tail feathers displayed, and a lion lying beside three sheep. Two long-necked birds fly on outstretched wings to the left of the Tree of Knowledge. A third bird perches in the uppermost branches of the tree on the left. A flock of sheep graze in the middle distance on the left. The background of the scene is dominated by a series of mountains with a waterfall spilling into a river or lake to the left of the Tree. A stag with large antlers and a second, indeterminate animal stand to the right of the waterfall.

component.illusobjdesc: In the lower right half of the design, the angel Raphael sits facing forward and left. He is gowned with long, slightly curly hair; his large wings extend to a point forming a Gothic arch above him. His arms are raised at 135 degrees. With his left hand he points upward (possibly towards Heaven?) while with his right he points toward the Tree of Knowledge in the distance. Raphael appears to be looking at Adam. His gown is at least semi-transparent. Some of his multiple wings curve downward, their shape and coloring suggesting flames. Raphael's left foot dangles downward; his right foot touches the ground on tiptoe.

Adam sits beside Eve in the left half of the design. He is nude with curly hair. He faces forward and right and looks up toward the Tree of Knowledge. Adam sits with his legs crossed at the ankles. His left arm is bent and his elbow rests on the table to the right. His left hand may rest on his chest with the fingers slightly spread. Adam's left foot is on tiptoe.

Eve sits beside Adam in the left half of the design. She is nude and her long, curly hair trails behind her right shoulder. Her right arm is down at her side; her right hand rests on the bench or chair she sits on with the palm down. Her left arm is bent upward with her left hand resting on her shoulder or possibly touching Adam. She faces forward and to the right with her head turned slightly down; she may be leaning on, or at least leaning toward, Adam. Her feet are on tiptoe.

Adam, Eve, and Raphael are seated on chairs or benches made of vegetative materials. The seats and tabletop appear to be covered in moss, while the bases or legs are made of interlacing leaves or branches (some with loops) of indeterminate vegetation. Some of the intertwined vegetation is suggestive of Gothic art.
A bowl filled with fruit and leaves, a bell-shaped goblet or chalice, and a large cup or pitcher with a looped handle sit on the table between Adam and Raphael.

The ground below the figures is covered with copious vegetation, inlcuding leaves, buds, and flowers. Several oak-like leaves are visible between the vegetative "legs" of the table. Large leafy laurel plants grow left and right of the scene; rose and lily blossoms spring from slender branches and arch over the entire scene. Small berries also grow among the leaves on both the left and right. In the lower left corner of the design, a lily plant bends to the right with most of its flowers on the ground. A rose plant mirrors this in the lower right corner of the design, bending left. The setting is Eden.

In the upper center of the design at the middle distance is the Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil. There are thorns on the trunk and along some of the branches. Multiple branches arch to the left and right of the central trunk and bear large fruits. There are few leaves on the tree, perhaps nine in all.
A serpent winds around the trunk of the Tree of Knowledge, its head facing right. The serpent is covered in scales. It has a beak-like nose and the serpent's head is topped with a spiky crest.
A horse stands or walks left of the Tree of Knowledge. Its body faces left, but its head is turned back to the right and up; it may be looking at the tree.
An elephant stands behind the Tree of Knowledge, facing left. Its mouth is open and a single tusk curves upward from its jaw. Its trunk arches downward.
A male peacock stands right of the Tree of Knowledge with its tail feathers displayed. Its body faces forward with its head turned to the right. Its beak appears to be open.
A male lion with a mane lies below the Tree of Knowledge, facing right but with his head turned forward.

Three sheep lie to the right of the lion. The middle sheep faces forward, head turned to the right; the two others face right. The first sheep from the left is horned. Its eyes are closed with its head down; it may be sleeping. The right-most sheep may also be sleeping.

Two long-necked birds fly on outstretched wings to the left of the Tree of Knowledge. The lower bird faces up while its partner faces left and down. The lower bird has a forked tail. A third bird perches in the uppermost branches of the tree on the left, its head turned to the right. A flock of sheep grazes in the middle distance on the left above Eve's right shoulder.
The area below the Tree of Knowledge may be covered in grass. A bush or plant grows just right of Adam's head.
The background of the scene is dominated by a series of mountains.
In the background to the left, a waterfall flows into a river or lake above Adam and Eve.
Trees grow to the left of the waterfall on a mountain or cliffside.
A stag with large antlers stands to the right of the waterfall, facing left. The odd shape right of the stag may be another animal, but of indeterminate species.
The sky is illuminated on the left but dark on the right.

desc.objtitle: The Rout of the Rebel Angels, Object 7 (Butlin 529.7)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Christ in heaven kneels on his right knee within the disc of the sun. He holds a large bow armed with seven arrows pointed at the rebel angels below. Six winged angels fly or hover alongside Christ, three on either side of the sun. Two of the angels have their arms bent with their palms held vertically and fingers spread. They look down toward the rebel angels and some wear an expression of surprise or awe. Fourteen figures representing the rebel angels fall into flames below Christ. Many of these figures are upside down and are shown in contracted or twisted positions with expressions of pain or fear. Satan is pictured in the center of the group. He is nude and has scales covering his genitals. His arms are bent and wrap around his head. His right hand disappears behind his head while his left rests on top of his head with the palm held vertically and the fingers bent. The fourteen rebel angels are surrounded by fire and smoke. Smoke or darkness rises left and right of the sun to the upper corners of the design.

component.illusobjdesc: Christ appears at the top of the design in heaven, his body circumscribed by the disc or orb of the sun. He is gowned and has long hair and a beard. He kneels with his left leg drawn up and his left foot visible below the hem of his garment. His torso is twisted to the left but his head faces down as he looks toward the rebel angels. Christ's left arm is extended downward and he holds a large bow in his left hand. His right arm is drawn back and he holds the bowstring taut with his right hand. He is about to shoot at least one arrow.

Christ holds a bow armed with seven arrows pointed down at the rebel angels. The shafts of most of the arrows are only faintly visible or disappear entirely within the disc of the sun, but all appear to radiate from the point where Christ holds the bowstring with his right hand.
Christ kneels within the disc of the sun. The sun and winged angels are surrounded by light or radiance. This part of the scene represents heaven.

Three winged angels fly or hover on either side of the sun. The angels on the left face forward and right while those on the right face forward and left. The angels on each side closest to the viewer are clearly gowned and both have curly hair. Their arms are bent upward in front of their chests with the palms held vertically and the fingers spread. Their gestures and expressions suggest surprise. The other angels have only their heads and the top of a single wing visible. Two of these angels have long hair. All of the angels appear to look toward the rebels below or toward Christ.

Fourteen figures representing the rebel angels fall into flames below Christ. The head and right shoulder of a fallen angel is pictured along the left border of the design. His head is turned up and to the right, and he is likely looking at Christ. He has slightly curly hair and a beard. His mouth is open and his expression suggests a combination of fear and pain.

Fourteen figures representing the rebel angels fall into flames below Christ. The upper body of a nude(?) figure is seen from behind along the left boder of the design, below the bearded head. The figure is upside down and faces away from the viewer. The figure's arms are bent and his right hand clutches his head with the fingers spread.
Fourteen figures representing the rebel angels fall into flames below Christ. In the lower left corner of the design, a bearded male head faces down in profile.

Fourteen figures representing the rebel angels fall into flames below Christ. Fourth from the left, a male figure falls upside down facing down. He appears to be gowned with the gown falling about his thighs, or short tights, leaving the rest of his legs bare. He is partially obscured by the nude figure to the right. Both legs are bent with the figure's right leg crossing in front of the nude male's right leg. At least one of his arms are bent wrapped around his head. His head is bent back and faces down in profile. His hair is slightly curly.

Fourteen figures representing the rebel angels fall into flames below Christ. Fifth from the left, a muscular nude male falls upside down and is seen from behind. His hips are twisted and his lower body faces to the left. His right leg is bent and is partially obscured by the gowned figure to the left; his left leg is not pictured. The figure's arms are bent and his hands rest together on the back of his head. His head is bent back slightly and faces down. His eyes may be closed or lowered; his hair is slightly curly.

Fourteen figures representing the rebel angels fall into flames below Christ. Sixth from the left, the head and right arm of a figure are visible. The figure falls upside down and faces out toward the viewer. The figure wears a crown or helmet. The figure's right arm is bent and wraps around his head.
Fourteen figures representing the rebel angels fall into flames below Christ. A head with curly hair is seen from behind just below the figure wearing a crown or helmet.

Fourteen figures representing the rebel angels fall into flames below Christ. Satan is pictured in the center of the group. He is muscular and nude and has scales covering his genitals. Satan falls upside down and faces out toward the viewer. Both legs are bent to the left with the feet prominent. His arms are bent and wrap around his head. His right hand disappears behind his head while his left rests on top of his head with the palm held vertically and the fingers bent. His hair is slightly curly.

Fourteen figures representing the rebel angels fall into flames below Christ. The upside down head of a figure is pictured below and to the left of Satan. The figure faces out toward the viewer with his mouth open and at least two teeth visible; he may be howling in pain or despair. The figure's hands appear to clutch the sides of his head, although the coloring of the left hand suggests that these may instead be flames surrounding the figure's head. A few lines on the right side of his head suggest that he wears a helmet.

Fourteen figures representing the rebel angels fall into flames below Christ. The upside down head and arms of a figure are pictured below and to the right of Satan. The figure has curly hair and faces down. Both arms are bent and his hands clutch at the sides of his head.

Fourteen figures representing the rebel angels fall into flames below Christ. A muscular nude male figure with curly hair falls upside down to the right of Satan. He faces down in profile with his left leg bent to the left and his right leg drawn up toward his chest. There is a faint outline of another (right?) leg and foot just above the figure's left leg, but it has been colored over with flames and smoke. This third leg is probably an earlier version (pentimento) of the figure's right leg, not quite canceled by coloring. His left arm is bent and his left hand clutches his head. A small sliver of his right arm is visible; he may hold it in a similar position to his left and clutch his head with both hands.

Fourteen figures representing the rebel angels fall into flames below Christ. The upper body of a nude male figure is pictured in the lower right corner of the design. The figure is upside down and seen from behind. His head is bent back and faces down. He has curly hair and his eyes may be closed or lowered. Both arms are bent with his hands clasped together as if in prayer; his chin may rest on his hands.

Fourteen figures representing the rebel angels fall into flames below Christ. A nude male figure falls in a twisted position near the right border of the design. His chest faces forward with his head bent back facing up. He has short curly hair and his mouth is open and teeth visible; he may be howling or shouting in pain or despair. His legs are bent with his calves and feet hidden from view. His arms are bent upward and wrap around his head, apparently with his hands behind his head.

Fourteen figures representing the rebel angels fall into flames below Christ. Only the head, hands, and part of the right arm of the rightmost (and uppermost) figure are visible. The figure faces forward and has curly hair. His mouth is open and the figure wears an expression of fear or despair. His hands clutch at the side of his face. His eyes are slightly raised.

The fourteen rebel angels are surrounded by flames and smoke. The sky left and right of the sun is also dark, perhaps because of rising smoke. The lower reaches of the scene apparently represent hell.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Christ stands facing left with a halo of light surrounding his body. His right hand is held above Eve with his palm down and fingers spread; Christ is in the act of forming or creating Eve. Eve hovers above the supine body of Adam. She looks toward Christ with her arms bent and hands together in prayer. Adam lies supine on a large leaf with his body horizontal. His head is bent back with his eyes closed; he is sleeping or is perhaps in a trance. The ground in Eden is covered in grass and many small plants with leaves, flowers, and buds. An indistinct forest of leafy trees extends left and right across the design above Adam. A crescent moon appears above Eve. The moon and darkness in the upper right corner of the design indicate a sky at night.

component.illusobjdesc: Christ stands facing left in profile with his left foot visible below the hem of his gown. He has long hair and a beard. His left arm is at his side while his right is raised at 135 degrees. His right hand is held above Eve with the palm down and the fingers spread; Christ is in the act of creating or forming Eve. A halo of light surrounds Christ's body; he looks at Eve's face.

Eve hovers or floats to the left of Christ with her legs together and feet touching. She is nude with long hair. She faces forward with her head turned to the right; she looks toward Christ. Eve's arms are bent upward in front of her chest with her hands together and the palms held vertically as if in prayer.

Adam lies supine on a large leaf at the bottom of the design. His body is horizontal with his head bent back and his eyes closed; he is sleeping or is perhaps in a trance. He is nude with his genitals exposed. Adam's right arm rests at his side with the palm facing up. His left arm is not pictured. His hair is long.

Adam lies on a large leaf at the bottom of the design. The ground around Adam is covered with other vegetation, including grass and several small plants bearing leaves, flowers, or buds. The scene is Eden.
A group of indistinct trees with visible trunks and large leafy tops appears above Adam and extends left and right across the design.
A crescent moon appears above Eve. The moon and darkness in the upper right corner of the design indicate a sky at night.

desc.objtitle: The Temptation and Fall of Eve, Object 9 (Butlin 529.9)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil stands in the center of the design. It has an intricate root system and its trunk rises behind Eve and the serpent. Multiple branches arch overhead bearing large fruits and leaves. Eve stands among the roots of the Tree of Knowledge. She holds the body of a snake (Satan in his serpent form) wrapped around her hips and cradles its head in her left hand. The serpent's tail coils around her feet and wraps its tail around her left calf. The serpent's mouth is open with its tongue and upper row of teeth visible. It holds a piece of fruit from the Tree of Knowledge in its mouth and offers it to Eve. Eve bends to the right and takes the fruit from the serpent's mouth in an eroticized parody of her kiss with Adam in the fifth illustration. Adam stands to the left of the Tree of Knowledge. He is nude and seen from behind. He holds a garland of flowers or fruit and leaves in his raised hands. A forest of leafy trees appears in the background with hills or mountains rising above. The background of the scene is dark and stormy. A large dark cloud with a single bolt of lightning appears to the right of the Tree of Knowledge. Two additional lightning bolts appear to the left of the Tree; one splits above and frames Adam's head. The events unfold in Eden.

component.illusobjdesc: Satan, in his serpent form, encircles Eve. The serpent's tail wraps around her left calf and ankle and its body climbs upward around her hips and left arm. Its head faces left and up in profile, looking at Eve; its head rests on Eve's left hand. The serpent is covered in scales and its head is topped with a spiky crest. Its mouth is open with the tongue and upper row of teeth visible. The serpent holds a piece of fruit from the Tree of Knowledge in its mouth and gives it to Eve in an eroticized parody of her kiss with Adam in the fifth illustration.

Adam stands to the left of the Tree of Knowledge. He is nude and is seen from behind. Both of his arms are bent with the palms facing out away from the viewer and the fingers on his right hand spread. In his hands he holds a garland of flowers or fruit and leaves. His head is turned left in profile. He looks up, eyes raised, towards the heavens and his mouth is open; his posture and expression suggests surprise. His hair is curly; his right leg is extended slightly backward his right foot is on tiptoe.
Adam holds a garland of flowers or fruit and leaves in his hands.
Adam stands on a mound or a small hill.

The Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil stands in the center of the design. It has an intricate root system and its trunk rises behind Eve and the serpent. Multiple branches arch overhead bearing large fruits and leaves. The scene is Eden.
A forest of leafy treessome with distinct trunksappears in the background left and right of the Tree of Knowledge.
Hills or mountains rise above the distant forest.

The background of the scene is dark and stormy. A large dark cloud with a single bolt of lightning appears to the right of the Tree of Knowledge. Two additional lightning bolts appear to the left of the Tree; one splits above and frames Adam's head.

lg.l: WBThe lower reaches of the letters are cut off by the trimmed lower edge of the leaf.

desc.objtitle: The Judgment of Adam and Eve: 'So Judged He Man', Object 10 (Butlin 529.10)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Christ stands in the center of the design between Adam (to the left) and Eve (to the right) with his arms bent upward and the palms facing out. He is gowned and a circular halo of light surrounds his head. Adam stands facing right with his right arm bent and his hands together in prayer. His head is bowed slightly. Eve stands facing left with her left hand and long hair obscuring her face, expressing shame. Both Adam and Eve wear loincloths or belts of oak(?) leaves. A serpent slithers along the ground behind the figures with its head, facing left, just left of Adam's raised heel. Its mouth is open with the tongue extended. The figures stand on a large leaf with small floweing plants (some perhaps lilies) below. A forest of leafy trees extends to the left and right of the figures and a band of clouds arches overhead, separating Christ, Adam, and Eve from Death and Sin above. Death, on the left, is gowned and wears a crown. He leans downward to the left of Adam and holds one of several darts or spears in his outstretched hands. Sin is nude and is encircled by two serpent's tails and three hound's heads, their mouths open with prominent tongues and teeth. She pours liquid from two vials to the right of Eve. The scene unfolds in Eden before the expulsion.

component.illusobjdesc: Christ stands in the center of the design between Adam and Eve. His hair is long and he has a beard. A halo of light surrounds his head. He is gowned and faces forward. Christ's arms are bent upward with the palms turned out toward the viewer and some of his fingers slightly spread. The hem of his garment covers his feet.

Adam stands to the left of Christ with his right leg bent and prominent right foot on tiptoe. He faces right in profile with his right arm bent and his hands held together in prayer. His head is slightly bowed and he may look down. His hair is curly. Adam is partly nude; his loins are covered by a loincloth or belt of oak(?) leaves.

Eve stands to the right of Christ with her right leg bent and right foot on tiptoe. She faces left in profile with her left arm bent upward and her hand on her face. Her long, somewhat curly hair covers the rest of her face and falls over her left shoulder. Her head is bent down slightly; her posture suggests shame or despair. Eve is partly nude; her loins are covered by a loincloth or belt of oak(?) leaves.

The serpent crawls or winds in an undulating pattern facing left. Scales cover the length of its body. Its head rests on the ground with its mouth open and tongue extended. The serpent's head is topped with a spiky crest.
Christ, Adam, and Eve all stand on a large leaf. The ground below the leaf is covered in arching plants, some with with lily-like flowers.
A forest of leafy trees appears in the distance to the left and right of Christ. Many of the trees have visible trunks, several of which split into branches just below their leaves.
An band of clouds arches above Christ, Adam, and Eve, separating them from the figures of Death and Sin above.

The figure of Death flies or hovers above and to the left of Christ. We see only his upper body, head, and arms. He faces left and down and may descend toward the figures below. Death is gowned and wears a crown. He has long hair and a beard. Both arms are extended to the left and he holds a spear or dart with both hands. The tips of at least ten other darts are pictured extending at various angles from Death's hands and arms.

The figure of Sin flies or hovers above and to the right of Christ. We see only her upper body, which is nude, head, and arms. She faces right and down and may descend toward the figures below. Her head is down and her long, somewhat flame-like, hair trails above her. Both arms are extended and Sin holds a vial in each hand; liquid pours from each vial toward the ground to the right of Eve. Two scaled serpent tails coil around Sin. Three dog's heads also appear around her; each has its mouth open with its toungue extended and teeth visible. They may be barking.
The scene, or at least the area below the cloud band, unfolds in Eden.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Christ is crucified upon a cross in the center of the design, raised on a mound or small hill. Above his head, the cross bears the Latin inscription INRI (Jesus of Nazareth, King of the Jews). A halo of radiance surrounds Christ's body; a few short lines indicating beams of light emanate from his head and upper torso. The satanic serpent coils around the base of the cross, its body lying in folds to the right. Its head is nailed to the cross by the same nail that pierces Christ's feet. Death (left) and Sin (right) lay supine at the foot of the cross with their heads down toward the viewer and their arms resting on the ground horizontally. Their eyes are closed; they are dead (that is, vanquished by Christ's sacrifice). Death wears a crown and may be covered by a cloth or drapery. The heads of three dogs, eyes closed and also apparently dead, rest on Sin's torso. The winged angel Michael stands to the left of the cross. He holds a spear and wears a crested helmet. His left arm is raised toward Christ with the palm turned out and fingers spread. Adam stands to the right of the cross with his left arm bent and his hands held together in prayer. He is nude and seen from behind. Eve rests in a small depression in the earth below the cross. She is nude. Her eyes are closed and she is probably sleeping. The ground below Eve is covered in grass with small flowers and leaves directly above Eve's body and left of her head.

component.illusobjdesc: Christ is sacrificed, crucified upon a cross in the center of the design. He is partly nude with a loincloth covering his hips and genitals. He wears a crown of thorns in his long hair. He is bearded and his head is tilted to the right and down, resting on his left shoulder. His eyes are closed, or at least partly closed. Christ's arms are raised horizontally with his palms down and fingers spread. His legs are together and are crossed at the ankles with his left foot prominent. A halo of radiance surrounds Christ's body; a few short lines indicating beams of light emanate from his head and upper torso. The dripping stain on the cross below and to the right of Christ's feet is probably his salvific blood.

Christ is crucified upon a cross in the center of the design. The cross is of course traditionally made of wood, although nothing in the design indicates as much. Three nails hold him to the cross; one through each palm and a third through his feet. Above Christ's head, the cross bears the inscription INRI, the Latin motto for Jesus of Nazareth, King of the Jews.

The satanic serpent coils around the base of the cross, its body lying in folds to the right. The serpent's body is covered in scales and its head is nailed to the cross by the same nail that pierces Christ's feet.

Death lies supine and dead (that is, vanquished) below and to the left of the cross. He is seen upside down with his head bent back to face the viewer and his eyes closed. He appears to be partly nude with a cloth or drapery covering his torso. Death is bearded and wears a pointed, spiky crown. His left leg is bent and drawn up. His arms rest on the ground in a position horizontal to his body. This posture suggests an upside-down crucifixion.

Sin lies supine and dead (that is, vanquished) below and to the right of the cross. She is seen upside down with her head toward the viewer and her eyes closed. She is nude, and her long hair fans out on the ground below her head. Her arms rest on the ground in a position horizontal to her body. Her right hand rests palm down on the ground. Her left arm may rest underneath Death's right shoulder and head. This posture suggests an upside-down crucifixion. The heads of three hounds also rest on Sin's torso with their eyes closed or at least partly closed. They are apparently also dead.

The winged angel Michael stands to the left of the cross. He is bearded and wears a crested helmet. He appears partly nude aside from indications of drapery on his torso. He faces forward with his head turned to face to the right; he looks up toward Christ. His left arm, pointing toward Christ, is raised at 135 degrees with the palm turned out, facing the viewer, and his fingers spread. His right arm is bent upward at his side and he holds a spear in his right hand. His right foot is on tiptoe.

Adam stands below and to the right of the cross. He is nude with curly hair and is seen from behind. His left leg is bent with the left foot on tiptoe. Adam's left arm is bent; his right arm is not visible, but his hands are held together before his chest in prayer. Adam's head is turned up in left profile with his eyes raised as he looks toward Christ.

Eve lies, partly supine and partly on her side, in a small depression in the earth below the cross. She is nude and her long, curly hair spreads out on the ground below her. Eve lies on her side; her body is horizontal with her torso twisted slightly. Her legs are together with the left leg bent, and her arms are at her sides. Her head is tilted up, but her eyes are closed and she is probably sleeping or in a trance.

The ground below Eve includes blades of grass. There may also be grass, or some low-growing plants, far right and far left (left of Eve's right shoulder). Flowers (some resembling lilies) and leaves appear immediately above Eve and left of her head.
The cross is raised on a mound or small hill, with small cliffs lower right and left. Eve lies in a depression the earth, oddly suggesting a very small valley, a bed, or a grave.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The winged angel Michael strides forward in the center of the design wearing a cloak or other drapery around his shoulders and a helmet with crown-like points and a large plume of feathers. He holds hands with Adam (to the left) and Eve (to the right) as he leads them out of Eden. Adam and Eve both wear loincloths or belts of oak(?) draped over their hips and genitals. Adam bends his right arm upward above his head with the palm held vertically. Eve's left arm is bent upward with the palm turned out. A serpent winds left and right of Michael with its crested head facing left and up and its mouth open with the tongue extended. The ground below the figures is covered in thorny vines, arching thistle plants right and left, and spiky leaves or grass. A swirled, coiled cloud flame appears above the figures. Four cheribum also appear at the top of the design. They are surrounded by flames and ride horses. Each cherubim also has a halo of light around his head. Four bolts of lightning extend from the upper reaches of the design to the ground. A fifth bolt appears just above Eve's head.

component.illusobjdesc: The winged angel Michael strides forward in the center of the design with his left leg prominent and at least his right foot on tiptoe. He is partly nude but wears a cloak or other drapery around his shoulders and upper arms. He is bearded and wears a helmet adorned with a large plume of feathers and points like those on a crown. His arms are raised at 45 degrees and he holds hands with Adam (to the left) and Eve (to the right) as he leads them out of Eden. Michael's eyes are raised to look upward and his hair may be slightly curly.

Adam strides or walks forward, both feet on tiptoe, to the left of Michael. He is partly nude with a loincloth or belt of oak(?) leaves draped over his hips and genitals. His hair is curly. Adam's left arm is bent at his side and he holds Michael's right hand with his left. Adam's right arm is bent upward with the palm held vertically above his head. His head is bent back and faces up and to the right in profile. His eyes are raised and he is likely looking at the horsemen above.

Eve strides or walks forward, both feet on tiptoe, to the right of Michael. She is partly nude with her breasts exposed and a loincloth or belt of oak(?) leaves draped over her hips and genitals. Her hair is long curly. Eve's right arm is at her side and she holds Michael's left hand with her right. Her left arm is bent upward with the palm turned out. Eve's head is bent back and faces up and to the left in profile. Her eyes are raised and she looks at the horsemen above. Her mouth is slightly open, suggesting awe or surprise.

A serpent lies slithering on the ground with its crested head turned left and up in profile between Michael's feet. Its mouth is open with the tongue extended. Its scaled body winds along the ground to the left and right of Michael.

Thorn-covered vines appear around Adam and Eve's feet; those near Adam are represented by thin lines while those near Eve are thicker and more substantial. Thorned thistle plants with large, spiky leaves appear in the lower left and lower right corners of the design; their stems arch towards the center of the image. A third thistle plant appears just to the right of Eve's lower left leg. Other leaves or tufts of grass cover the ground below the figures' feet. The setting is east of Eden.

A large, coiled and smoky flame appears above Michael, Adam and Eve. Tongues of flame and smoke extend outward from the cloud, reaching to the left and right of Adam and Eve and also upward between the pairs of cherubim and their horses.
Four bolts of lightning strike the ground around Adam and Eve. A fifth bolt appears directly above Eve's head.
A few parallel, horizontal lines suggest steps or stairs behind the upper legs of the three figures in the bottom section of the design.

The heads of four cherubim appear at the top of the design, with two on either side of the coiled cloud. They probably ride the horses whose heads are pictured below them. The cheribum face forward, though the figure furthest to the right turns slightly to the left and may look at his companion. Each figure is bearded and has long hair. A halo of light surrounds each figure's head.

The head of a horse appears below each of the four cheribum at the top of the design. They face forward, toward the viewer. The horse third from the left is partially obscured by the coiled flame. Fire appears to extend downward from mouths of the horses second and fourth from the left.
